questions.question: Which of the following is a selective alpha 1 receptor antagonist?
Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding prazosin?

options.A: Blocks all subtypes of alpha 1 receptors
options.B: It is only an arteriolar dilator
options.C: It has a beneficial effect on lipid profile

questions.explanation: Prazosin causes dilation of both arterioles and veins.As a result, both afterload and preload decrease. However, the reflex tachycardia is lesspronounced due to the absence of ° 2 blockade.Prazosin blocks all subtypes of the ° 1 receptor (° 1A, ° 1B, and ° 1D). It also has a beneficial effecton lipid profile as it decreases LDL and triglycerides and increases HDL levels.

questions.question: In which of the following patients would prazosin not be used therapeutically?
questions.explanation: Prazosin is not useful to treat a patient with ejaculatory dysfunction. It is indicated in relievingsymptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).Prazosin is an ° 1 receptor antagonist and is useful in:••Relieving vasospasm in peripheral vascular diseases⚫ Controlling the symptoms of pheochromocytoma preoperatively (as an alternative tophenoxybenzamine)• Mainstay treatment for scorpion sting along with antivenom137

questions.question: A patient presents with complaints of dizziness while getting up from bed. He tells you he wasrecently diagnosed with BPH and has been taking prazosin. Which of the following drugswould be a good replacement for him?
questions.explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of postural hypotension caused by prazosin. These symptoms canbe avoided by using silodosin which has a selective antagonist action on ° 1A receptors over ° 1Breceptors.The prostate stroma has a maximum concentration of ° 1A receptors over other ° 1 receptorsubtypes. ° 1B receptors are present on blood vessels which play a role in vasoconstriction. Hence,selective 1A receptor antagonists have minimal effect on blood pressure as compared tonon-selective ° 1 antagonists like prazosin.○1 receptor antagonists can be classified as:•Selective antagonists• Silodosin (° 1A)• Tamsulosin (° 1A + ° 1D)• Non-selective• Prazosin• Terazosin• Doxazosin• Alfuzosin

questions.question: A 62-year-old male presents with complaints of a weak urine stream and frequent urinationin small amounts for the past month. He also mentions that he often feels lightheaded andhas low blood pressure. Which of the following alpha-blockers will you prefer to give him?
questions.explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and tamsulosin should begiven to this patient as it has the least effect on blood pressure.It is an ° -blocker that has more selectivity towards ° 1A/1D when compared to ° 1B receptors. Thevasodilatory effects are mainly attributed to the blockade of ° 1B receptors present on bloodvessels.The relief of BPH symptoms is mainly due to the blockade of ° 1A receptors presentpredominantly in the prostatic stroma. It lacks the apoptotic effect on prostatic cells that is seenwith terazosin and doxazosin.

questions.question: You prescribe tamsulosin to a patient with benign prostatic hyperplasia. What is the mainside effect that should be explained to the patient?
questions.explanation: Retrograde ejaculation is the main side effect of tamsulosin.It is a selective ° 1A/1D blocker and the relief of BPH symptoms is mainly due to blockade of ° 1Areceptors. Blockade of ° 1D receptors present in the bladder relaxes the urethral sphincter, whichis normally closed during ejaculation. This results in the redirection of semen into the urinarybladder.138Silodosin causes ejaculatory dysfunction due to absence of seminal emission.

questions.question: Which of the following is a selective alpha 2 receptor antagonist?
questions.explanation: Yohimbine is a competitive antagonist that is selective for ° 2 receptors. It was earlier used in theindication of erectile dysfunction but is rarely indicated now due to better results with PDE5inhibitors.Terazosin and alfuzosin are selective alpha 1 receptor antagonists.Yasmin (drospirenone) is a 4th generation progestin used as an oral contraceptive havingmineralocorticoid antagonist action.

questions.question: Phenoxybenzamine is indicated in the management of which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: Phenoxybenzamine is indicated in the preoperative preparation of patients withpheochromocytoma. It is also indicated for symptomatic control in inoperable and advancedpheochromocytoma.Option B: Phenoxybenzamine is not used in the management of essential hypertension because ofthe irreversible alpha blockade and increased risk of adverse effects.Option C: For erectile dysfunction, intracavernous phentolamine, a reversible non-selectivealpha-blocker is indicated.

questions.question: A patient with erectile dysfunction complained of unsatisfactory response to oral medication.He was then administered an intracavernosal injection of phentolamine following which hedeveloped sustained painful erection. Which of the following can be used to reverse hiscondition?
questions.explanation: The reversal of phentolamine induced priapism (painful erection) can be achieved byintracavernosal injection of phenylephrine.Intracavernosal phentolamine (° -blocker) is used for the management of impotency. Priapism is aserious adverse effect of this agent. Phenylephrine is an ° agonist and counteracts phentolamineinduced priapism by producing vasoconstriction.Phentolamine is useful in:• Hypertensive crisis due to clonidine withdrawal•Short term control of intra-operative hypertension in patients with pheochromocytoma• MAO inhibitor-induced hypertension in cheese reactionOptions A and B: Phenoxybenzamine and prazosin are ° -receptor antagonists and can worsenpriapism.Option D: Propranolol is a non-selective ẞ-blocker and is not indicated in this condition.139

questions.question: In which of the following conditions is propanolol not indicated?
questions.explanation: Propranolol is not indicated in variant angina. It can cause further constriction of coronaryarteries by leaving alpha-mediated coronary vasoconstriction unopposed.Uses of propranolol include:• Management of thyrotoxicosis• Management of hypertension (however, cardioselective beta-blockers are now preferred overnon-selective)• Treatment of infantile hemangioma• Management of essential tremors and panic attacks••Prophylaxis of migraine•Prevention of variceal bleeding in portal hypertension

questions.question: A 45-year-old man is diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus during a routine healthevaluation. He mentions that he is on propranolol for essential tremors. You would cautionhim against continuing the drug due to what reason?
questions.explanation: Propranolol is generally avoided in diabetic patients because it masks the hypoglycaemicsymptoms.Non-selective ẞ blockers interfere with the counter-regulatory hormones secreted duringhypoglycemia, resulting in prolonged hypoglycemia. It also decreases the perception of symptomssuch as tremors, tachycardia, and nervousness. These symptoms are manifested due tostimulation of sympathetic beta receptors in response to hypoglycemia. Blunting of sympatheticresponse results in hypoglycemic unawareness.Cardioselective beta-blockers have relatively lesser interference on the sympathetic response tohypoglycemia and are preferred in diabetic patients.

questions.question: 132Propranolol is drug of choice for:
questions.explanation: Propranolol is the drug of choice in the management of infantile hemangioma complicated byulceration or in symptomatic patients.It acts by causing vasoconstriction, inducing apoptosis and inhibition of angiogenesis.

questions.question: Which of the following is a cardioselective beta blocker with antioxidant property?
questions.explanation: Nebivolol is a cardioselective beta-blocker with additional antioxidant property.Nebivolol:•Nebivolol is a third-generation, long-acting, and highly selective ẞ1 adrenergic receptorantagonist140•It stimulates NO-mediated vasodilation via ẞ3 receptor agonism• Nebivolol is approved for the treatment of hypertension•It has potential utility in the treatment of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction• Nebivolol reduces oxidative stress and may have favorable effects on both carbohydrate and lipidmetabolism• This can be used in metabolic syndrome.

questions.question: Esmolol is indicated in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: Esmolol is a short-acting cardioselective beta-blocker that is indicated in:• Prevention and management of intraoperative tachycardia•• Postoperative hypertension•Supraventricular tachycardia.Hypertensive emergencyIt is contraindicated in pulmonary hypertension.

questions.question: Which of the following is a false statement?

options.A: Metoprolol prolongs survival in congestive cardiac failure
options.C: Esmolol is mainly metabolised in the liver

questions.explanation: Esmolol contains an ester linkage and it is hydrolyzed rapidly by esterases in erythrocytes and notin the liver. This results in a short half-life of about 8-10 minutes.It is used in the management of intraoperative and postoperative hypertension as it has a shortduration of action and can be discontinued quickly.Option A: Metoprolol is approved for use in chronic congestive cardiac failure and has shownmortality benefit.Option B: Celiprolol has shown a relaxant effect on vascular smooth muscle and weak vasodilationdue to partial selective ẞ2 agonism.Option D: Nebivolol has the additional action of releasing nitric oxide.

questions.question: Identify the third-generation beta-blocker that does not cause alpha 1 receptor antagonism.133
questions.explanation: Celiprolol is a third-generation beta blocker having no action on ° 1 receptors. It causesvasodilation by partial selective ẞ2 agonist activity.Labetalol, carvedilol, and bucindolol are non-selective third-generation beta blockers that possessadditional 1 receptor antagonistic action. This is responsible for their vasodilatory effect.Note: Third-generation ẞ-blockers are those that possess additional vasodilating actions andinclude cardioselective and non-selective drugs.141

questions.question: You are about to add a beta-blocker to the treatment chart of a patient with heart failure.Which of the following is not true about the use of these drugs in this condition?

options.B: Most effective in acute decompensated heart failure
options.C: Should be started at a low dose
options.D: Carvedilol is widely used in this condition

questions.explanation: ẞ-blockers are contraindicated in the treatment of acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF) asthey can worsen the condition. They are indicated only in patients with chronic stable heartfailure.Option A: Though contraindicated in ADHF, it is safe to start once the patient is euvolemic.Initiation of ẞ-blocker prior to discharge is associated with improved outcomes and must becontinued after discharge.Option C: B-blockers are initiated at a low dose and slowly titrated to decrease the risk ofprecipitating heart failure.Option D: Carvedilol has been shown to reduce mortality in patients with heart failure, and iswidely used because of additional benefits like antioxidant properties and peripheral vasodilatoryaction.

questions.question: Which of the following is not true about beta-blockers?

options.A: Atenolol is longer acting than metoprolol
options.B: Labetalol has both alpha and beta blocking action

questions.explanation: Celiprolol is excreted predominantly through the renal route. It is excreted unchanged in theurine.Option A: Atenolol is longer acting with a longer half-life than metoprolol. It is usuallyadministered once daily.Option C: Labetalol is a non-selective ẞ-blocker with ° 1 blocking action similar to carvedilol.Option D: Nadolol has the longest half-life of 20 hours and is administered once daily.

questions.question: A nurse in the nephrology ward is managing the drug inventory for patients with severe renalfailure. Which of the following beta-blockers is least likely to be present in the drug charts?
questions.explanation: Sotalol is least likely to be present in the treatment charts as it is contraindicated in severe renalfailure. It has low lipid solubility and is excreted primarily unchanged in the urine.Carvedilol, metoprolol and labetalol are metabolised by the liver and can be used in renal failure.

questions.question: Beta-blockers are not indicated in which of the following patients?134

options.B: 35-year-old factory worker with alcohol withdrawal40-year-old chronic alcoholic with portal hypertensiond) 22-year-old singer with performance anxietyQuestion 21:Which of the following is a selective beta 2 antagonist?a) Betaxololb) Butoxamine

questions.explanation: Beta-blockers are not indicated in hypothyroidism. They are indicated in hyperthyroidism andthyrotoxicosis that manifests with increased sympathetic activity.Options B and C: Beta-blockers are useful in the treatment of alcohol withdrawal and in reducingvariceal bleeding in portal hypertension.Option D: ẞ blockers like propranolol are effective in controlling acute panic symptoms andanxiety associated with performing in public. They reduce symptoms of increased sympathetic142activity such as tachycardia and tremors.

questions.question: Cocaine-like effect of inhibiting neuronal uptake of noradrenaline is seen with which of thefollowing?
questions.explanation: Cocaine-like effect of inhibiting neuronal uptake of noradrenaline (NE) is seen with labetalol.It is a third-generation non-selective ẞ blocker with the following actions:●• Non-selective ẞ receptor blockade• Selective ° 1 receptor blockade• Inhibition of neuronal uptake of NE/cocaine-like effect

questions.question: Match the following beta-blockers with their receptor selectivity and additional actions.
questions.explanation: Pindolol is a non-selective first-generation ẞ-blocker with significant intrinsic agonist activity,which may result in a smaller reduction in heart rate and blood pressure. This is useful in patientswith diminished cardiac reserve or at risk of bradycardia.Carvedilol is a non-selective third-generation ẞ-blocker with antioxidant and anti-inflammatoryproperties. These properties make it useful in the treatment of congestive heart failure.Betaxolol is a ẞ1 selective third-generation ẞ-blocker with additional calcium entry blockadeactivity and a slight membrane-stabilizing property. It does not have agonist activity.Acebutolol is a ẞ1 selective second-generation ẞ blocker having both membrane-stabilizing andintrinsic agonist activity. It is useful in the treatment of atrial and ventricular arrhythmias.PindololNon-selective, intrinsic agoniNon-selective, antioxidantstCarvedilolBetaxololBeta 1 selective, membrane stabilizingAcebuto Beta 1 selective, intrinsic agololnist143
